Social Life and Friendships

Human beings were created for connection. God said,

“It is not good that the man should be alone” (Genesis 2:18)
, highlighting our natural need for companionship and community. In a Christian lifestyle, social life and friendships should be guided by the principles of God’s Word. The people we associate with have a strong influence on our thoughts, habits, and spiritual direction. Ellen White wrote,
“The influence of association is never neutral. It is powerful for good or for evil” (Messages to Young People, p. 411).
Choosing the right companions is a matter of eternal importance.

Friendship That Builds Character

The Bible teaches that

“He that walketh with wise men shall be wise: but a companion of fools shall be destroyed” (Proverbs 13:20).
True Christian friendships help us grow in faith, strengthen our walk with God, and encourage us to do good. Friends should pray together, study the Bible together, and hold one another accountable. Ellen White advised,
“Let those who profess to be Christians be careful with whom they associate” (Child Guidance, p. 114).
The right friends will lead us closer to Christ, not away from Him.

Avoiding Corrupting Associations

While we are to love and witness to all, close friendships with those who disregard God’s principles can weaken our convictions. Paul cautioned,

“Be not deceived: evil communications corrupt good manners” (1 Corinthians 15:33).
Many young Christians have been led into sin through unwise associations. Ellen White warned,
“Familiarity with unbelievers for the sake of pleasure or worldly enjoyment will be a snare to the soul” (Messages to Young People, p. 444).
We must ask ourselves if our friendships are building us spiritually, or breaking us.

Being a Christian Influence in Society

While we are called to be separate from the world in spirit, we are not to isolate ourselves from society. Jesus mingled with people, not to conform, but to transform. Our lives should reflect the light of Christ in every social setting. Ellen White encouraged social engagement for mission, saying,

“If we would elevate others, we must come near to them” (The Ministry of Healing, p. 143).
Christian social life is active, not passive—it seeks opportunities to share truth and model Christlike love.

Balance in Social Life

Social life, even among believers, must not take the place of communion with God or personal duty. While fellowship is a blessing, we must guard our time and energy to ensure our priorities are right. Jesus often withdrew from the crowds to pray and connect with His Father (Luke 5:16). Ellen White advised,

“Let the youth guard against being satisfied with a superficial experience in religious things” (Messages to Young People, p. 99).
A balanced Christian life includes both wholesome social interactions and deep personal devotion.

Conclusion

The Christian’s social life and friendships are not just a part of life, they are part of our spiritual journey. Every relationship either draws us closer to Christ or pulls us away. By choosing godly companions and being a godly friend, we build up the body of Christ and prepare for the fellowship of heaven. Ellen White’s counsel rings true:

“True friendship is a help and a safeguard to the soul” (Messages to Young People, p. 441).
Let us walk with those who walk with God.
